Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 61(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant worked in China for a Canadian company with minimal time spent in Canada; employment deemed not temporary and no plans to return to work in Canada.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 730-day physical presence requirement over five years
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Employment records, duration of stay in Canada, nature and terms of foreign assignment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating temporary nature of foreign employment or intent to return to work in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found applicant's claim of temporary assignment unconvincing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; residency obligation not met
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reinstatement of permanent resident status based on residency compliance
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Assignment abroad was not temporary; insufficient connection maintained with Canadian employer; no intention to return to work in Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate consideration refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Refusal of H&C Grounds for Residency Non-Compliance
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28 of IRPA (implied through H&C provisions)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants spent minimal time in Canada, failed residency obligations, and had limited ties to Canada; H&C factors did not outweigh non-compliance
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with minimum physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of IAD decision on H&C grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Ties to Canada, family connections, employment history, reasons for absence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of exceptional hardship or compelling circumstances justifying relief
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: H&C claims found less persuasive compared to failure to meet legal obligations
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD rejected humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal dismissed; permanent residence status not reinstated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status retained on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review setting aside IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary assessment of H&C factors under s.25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: H&C considerations did not outweigh the applicants’ failure to meet statutory residency obligations

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 28(2)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Jin was absent from Canada for 1,118 days; claimed full-time employment abroad with J Brother and Dragon Mart but provided insufficient proof of remuneration and inconsistent documentation.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 730-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues due to inconsistent testimonies and lack of verifiable employment records
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal dismissed by IAD; judicial review sought and dismissed by Federal Court
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian immigration authorities' jurisdiction over permanent resident obligations
Evidence_Used: Business documents from J Brother and Dragon Mart
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of remuneration, inconsistent employment records, insufficient documentation of full-time status
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found Jin's evidence not credible due to inconsistencies and gaps in documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; removal order upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on full-time employment exception and humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Jin failed to demonstrate full-time employment by a Canadian business abroad and lacked strong humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to prolonged absence and weak ties to Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency obligation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Full-time employment abroad by a Canadian business and humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, administrative law principles
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Removal order issued and appeal dismissed
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent Resident claiming exemption from residency requirement
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Not applicable – case focused on immigration compliance, not persecution
Crimes.Credibility: Assessed as low due to inconsistent testimony and lack of supporting documentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer reasonably refuse Grusas' work permit application based on lack of required experience?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed Grusas' judicial review, upholding the visa officer's decision.
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of required cooking experience despite other qualifications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant lacked three years of cooking experience as required by LMO and NOC
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe applicant cannot perform the required work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant’s qualifications versus job-specific experience requirement

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet work permit requirements under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet work experience requirements for work permit
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA Regulations s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Grusas lacked three years of cooking experience as required by LMO and NOC
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for work permit
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the refusal was procedurally fair and adequately reasoned
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Job requirements, LMO, NOC standards, applicant's qualifications
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented three years of cooking experience
Crimes.Outcome: Court found decision reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of work permit refusal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds under s.200(3)(a)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusion aligned with objective job requirements and legal standards
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to answer truthfully under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision based on misrepresentation was reasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant lacked credibility due to submission of fraudulent test results
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Submission of forged English test report that could induce error in immigration assessment
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of falsified language proficiency results in application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and defensibility under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of misrepresentation on points-based eligibility for permanent residency
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applicants found inadmissible for two years

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's dismissal based on misrepresentation was reasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant lacked credibility due to forged IELTS test submission
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Initial submission of forged test report, regardless of subsequent valid tests
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of falsified language test to meet application requirements
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and defensibility under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Potential to induce error in immigration decision-making process
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applicants remain inadmissible for two years

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's decision was patently unreasonable or involved an error of law
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 28(1)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 28(1) - Residency obligation of 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Only 360 days of physical presence in Canada between 1997 and 2002
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), followed by judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with IRPA s. 28(1) residency requirement
Crimes.Application_Factor: Time spent outside Canada without authorization under deemed presence rules
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 28(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Angeles spent only 360 days in Canada from 1997 to 2002
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness in IAD proceedings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Angeles failed to provide sufficient evidence or documentation to support appeal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD upheld removal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, reinstatement of permanent resident status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under IRPA s. 28(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error or patently unreasonable finding by IAD

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirements, credibility assessment, humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Failure to meet residency requirements, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records, testimony
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to meet residency obligations, negative credibility finding, lack of compelling H&C factors
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for facts, reasonableness for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of credibility and residency under IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictory testimonies and criminal record
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lease agreements, employment records, tax returns, criminal record
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations, residency compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence, fraud convictions, inconsistent statements
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for H&C; patent unreasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Compliance with residency obligation under IRPA section 28
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records deemed insufficient
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove 730 days of residency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Permanent residents must reside in Canada for 730 days within five years
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records, testimony
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged IAD's credibility and residency findings

Evidence_Sufficiency: Police reports of acquitted charges were admitted without verification
Evidence_Credibility: Admitted evidence was neither credible nor trustworthy
Credibility_Assessment: IAD failed to properly assess credibility of police reports
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 72(1)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Conviction on possession charge; acquittal on related charges
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural fairness violation due to use of acquitted charges
Legal_Framework: Admissibility standard: credible and trustworthy evidence
Risk_Factor: Potential risk due to nature of offense
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 72(1)

Aggravating_Factors: Mischaracterization of crime as sexual offense despite acquittal
Evidence_Sufficiency: Reliance on unproven allegations and acquitted charges
Evidence_Credibility: Admitted reports not verified; based on acquitted charges
Credibility_Assessment: IAD failed to respect judicial findings of acquittal
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 72(1)

Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of probation breaches, not sexual offenses
Procedural_Issue: Admission of inadmissible evidence; mischaracterization of offenses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Use of non-credible, unverified police reports
Credibility_Assessment: IAD improperly assessed credibility of acquitted allegations
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; IAD decision set aside
Decision_Rationale: Improper conflation of probation breaches with sexual offenses

Legal_Issue: Did the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD) reasonably deny Shaath's appeal for humanitarian and compassionate grounds despite his failure to meet residency obligations?
Evidence_Type: Evidence of hardship or establishment in Canada
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to meet 730-day physical presence requirement
Insufficient evidence of hardship or establishment in Canada

Application_Facts: Mr. Acharige argued that the PRRA Officer erred in assessing his risk claims; he claimed risks in Sri Lanka due to political involvement and alleged murder ties.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal after judicial review application
Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, RPD findings, applicant's submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Arguments found speculative and unsupported by credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD and PRRA Officer both concluded Mr. Acharige was not at risk in Sri Lanka; lack of credibility in risk claims
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending resolution of risk claims
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue
Decision_Rationale: Court found arguments speculative and lacking credible evidence; prior decisions found no risk in Sri Lanka
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court (judicial review), PRRA Officer (administrative decision)

Application_Facts: The applicant provided letters but failed to address prior credibility issues.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA applications are not second refugee claims.
The officer reasonably assigned low probative value due to lack of detail and objectivity.
Evidence_Used: Personal supporting documentation, including letters from interested parties
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detail, hearsay, lack of objectivity
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found prior credibility issues unaddressed; assigned low probative value to evidence
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of negative PRRA decision
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question and overturning of the decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing PRRA officer's evaluation of evidence
Decision_Rationale: PRRA officer did not err in law; properly exercised discretion in weighing evidence with low probative value

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Officer relied on a BBC News article indicating improved conditions in Sri Lanka, which was not disclosed to the applicant and contradicted the applicant's evidence.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose novel and significant documentary evidence affecting decision-making
Evidence_Used: BBC News article on country conditions in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose reliance on external documentary evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence was discounted without opportunity to respond to contradictory information
Decision_Outcome: Negative decision based on undisclosed evidence
Remedy_Sought: Case remitted to a new Officer for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Decision_Rationale: The Officer breached the duty of fairness by failing to disclose reliance on changing country conditions and related documentary evidence
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on lack of durable solution prospects
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 139(1)(d) of IRPR
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone's civil war and applied for permanent residence but were found inadmissible due to involvement with the Civil Defense Unit
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer did not assess compelling reasons exception under section 108(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Finding of no reasonable prospect of durable solutions elsewhere
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explicit finding of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applications dismissed except for complicity determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed applications except complicity finding quashed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence in Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Officer Blouin's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 108(4) exception for compelling reasons in cases of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 108(4) not triggered due to absence of finding of past persecution

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity during Sierra Leone civil war
Crimes.Outcome: Complicity determination quashed, application dismissed on other grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Involvement with Civil Defense Unit during conflict
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Complicity finding set aside, application dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Credibility: Persecution claims not meeting 'appalling' or 'atrocious' threshold

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Respondent be held in contempt for failing to pay a fine and costs?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 466(1)(b) and Rule 471 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence confirmed service of the April 7, 2006 Order and non-compliance by the Respondent
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Met by the Applicant through testimony on service and non-payment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondent did not appear or provide valid justification
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Non-compliance with court orders may result in contempt, fines, costs, and imprisonment
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of compliance with court order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to pay $2,000 fine and $1,000 costs as ordered
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Warrant of Committal and additional costs
Crimes.Outcome: Warrant of Committal issued; additional costs of $1,000 assessed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a court order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with financial obligations under court order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: April 7, 2006 Court Order requiring payment of fine and costs
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 466(1)(b) and Rule 471 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent failed to pay $2,000 fine and $1,000 costs despite service and reminders
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ex parte motion filed due to Respondent's non-appearance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent offered irrelevant documents instead of compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Warrant of Committal issued; additional $1,000 costs imposed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Imprisonment via Warrant of Committal and recovery of additional costs
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Imprisonment and monetary sanction
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Contempt for failure to comply with court order
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective review of compliance with court directive
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Willful non-compliance with clear court order after proper notice

Legal_Provision_Violated: Principle of Procedural Fairness in Refugee Protection Division proceedings
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed based on perceived lack of evidence rebutting the presumption of state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to question applicants about key documentary evidence; did not allow response to adverse information
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence submitted by applicants, hearing transcripts, RPD decision reasons
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD inadequately addressed contradictory evidence provided by applicants
Remedy_Sought: Remittal to a differently constituted RPD for redetermination
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with respect to procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: RPD breached procedural fairness by failing to properly consider evidence and permit applicant response

Violation_Type: Failure to establish proper nexus to a Convention ground
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 96, 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Sri Lankan Tamil individual fled persecution; associated with passengers aboard MV Sun Sea; claimed fear of persecution based on ethnicity and association
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review for mixed questions of law and fact
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's jurisdiction under IRPA subsection 72(1) for judicial review
Evidence_Used: RPD findings on Tamil ethnicity and association with MV Sun Sea passengers
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Deficiencies in linking association with MV Sun Sea to Convention grounds
Decision_Outcome: RPD granted refugee status based on nexus to Convention ground of race (Tamil ethnicity)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; RPD decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's refugee status determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus between fear of persecution and a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: RPD's finding of nexus based on race (Tamil ethnicity) was reasonable; deficiencies in other factors did not undermine the overall decision

Application_Facts: Applicant withdrew sponsorship application due to income ineligibility and later requested reconsideration; immigration officer refused, citing functus officio.
Procedural_Issue: Officer incorrectly applied functus officio doctrine and failed to exercise residual discretion to reconsider the withdrawn application.
Evidence_Used: Evidence that the officer had discretion to reconsider the application.
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found error in the officer's application of functus officio.
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted to another immigration officer for reconsideration.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Administrative decision-makers retain discretion to reconsider decisions unless legally barred.
Decision_Rationale: The functus officio doctrine does not apply where a decision-maker retains residual discretion to reopen or reconsider a matter; the officer erred in refusing to consider reopening.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed due to procedural errors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical records, social service reports, internet research (not disclosed)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4(2) of IRPA regarding best interests of the child
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children without hardship threshold
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied hardship threshold in best interests assessment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Inadequacies in medical care, risk of homelessness, dependency on social services in St. Lucia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correct legal test under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children's vulnerability and integration in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for best interests of the child and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to lack of candor
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4(2) of IRPA regarding best interests of the child
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied hardship threshold and used undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Unique consequences of removal including medical and social risks
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and correct legal test
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on non-disclosed evidence affecting fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in identity or supporting documents

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada upon expiration of authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tisson remained in Canada beyond her visa validity
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of undisclosed evidence by decision maker
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure of relied-upon evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially undermined due to unauthorized stay
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child without hardship threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Improper focus on hardship rather than best interests

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of best interests of children in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found lacking due to perceived deceitful behavior
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children in St. Lucia
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Inadequate healthcare, homelessness risk, social service gaps

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Legality of work without proper permit
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to consider full context of removal impact
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Undermined by unauthorized work and stay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Best interests of child must be primary consideration
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Error in assessment led to unreasonable outcome
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s. 25(1) and administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasis on compliance and rule of law
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical reports, school records, housing status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 84 of IRPA (duty to leave Canada)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tisson remained in Canada after issuance of removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of undisclosed evidence in original decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose relied-upon evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Impacted by history of non-compliance
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on H&C grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by new decision maker
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flawed analysis focusing on hardship instead of best interests
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency and IRCC

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for permanent residency; claimed work experience under NOC 4162; submitted financial documents deemed unreliable
Residency_Compliance: N/A - application was rejected prior to granting of status
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of credible financial documentation
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to assess work experience under applicant's chosen NOC category (4162); did not provide opportunity to respond to concerns about document credibility
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of valid work experience under correct NOC code
Credibility_Assessment: Financial documents found not credible; no chance given to address concerns
Decision_Outcome: Application rejected due to insufficient work experience points and unreliable financial documents
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer erred in applying NOC categories and breached procedural fairness by not allowing applicant to respond
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Application_Facts: Kincolith Band used Marlon Watts' land without permission from 1985 for communication equipment; trespass continued past 1996 statement of claim
Procedural_Issue: Default judgment granted in 1999 due to non-contestation; damages determined via reference hearing
Decision_Outcome: Damages limited to period before statement of claim (1985–1996); future claims require new action
Outcome: Plaintiff awarded $10,300 in damages, $5,281.95 in costs, and interest
Relief_Sought: Damages for unauthorized use of land
Legal_Standard_Applied: Under common law, damages only for losses accrued before commencement of action
Decision_Rationale: Continuing damages not allowed beyond date of statement of claim without specific rules permitting otherwise
Authority_Responsible: Court granting default judgment and determining damages

Application_Facts: Applicant Qureshi denied citizenship due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements and procedural fairness concerns regarding an anonymous letter.
Residency_Compliance: Judge found non-compliance with three-year residency requirement within four-year period
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to reliance on anonymous letter
Evidence_Used: Anonymous letter, applicant's evidence with inconsistencies
Credibility_Assessment: Judge assessed applicant's credibility as lacking due to inconsistent evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Disclosure of prejudicial information for procedural fairness; Residency under s. 5(1)(c)
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness; Reasonableness for residency determination
Decision_Rationale: Procedural fairness upheld because contents of anonymous letter were disclosed and applicant responded; Residency requirement not met based on inconsistent evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 114 or s. 129
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged errors in fact-finding during H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Applicant claims incorrect facts used (e.g., sponsorship eligibility)

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 114 or s. 129
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged factual inaccuracies in H&C decision (e.g., spouse's sponsorship ability)
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Factual errors claimed but not proven to cause irreparable harm

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a narcotic for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to family member’s criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA, s. 36(2)(a) – family member inadmissible on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant has three Canadian-born children; husband (PR) convicted of drug offenses
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant is foreign national seeking H&C relief

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry or re-entry into Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Inadmissibility on criminal grounds and failure to comply with departure order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was deported based on a valid conviction for mischief; later acquitted but did not file judicial review within required time frame
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deportee seeking to overturn removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to illegal re-entry after deportation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late filing of application for judicial review beyond statutory deadline
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, acquittal decision, deportation order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of justification for delay in filing judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly assessed; focus on procedural timeliness
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Quashing of deportation order based on subsequent acquittal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and extension of time to file
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of delay and likelihood of success on merits
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Deportation order valid when issued; acquittal does not retroactively invalidate order; delay unjustified

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 36(1) - Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of mischief, deported, later acquitted, challenged deportation order after 15-day review period
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident found inadmissible due to criminal conviction
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain lawful status post-conviction
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to file judicial review within 15 days; request for extension denied
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court’s authority to grant leave for late applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction, appellate acquittal, immigration file
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient explanation for delay in filing application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; issue centered on legal timing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for extension and judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn deportation order based on quashed conviction
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Extension of time to apply for judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Test for granting extension: explanation for delay and merit of claim
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Order lawful at time of issuance; IRPA does not require automatic reversal upon acquittal; delay unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether a deportation order based on a conviction can stand after the conviction is overturned
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-acquittal judicial review of immigration decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed validity of original conviction and impact of appellate acquittal
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant bore burden to justify delay and show viable legal basis
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not central; legal effect of acquittal was key
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions based on lawful facts at time of decision remain valid despite subsequent changes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conviction overturned on appeal; argued deportation order should be void
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; no retroactive invalidation of deportation order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Original trial record, appellate court decision, immigration hearing transcript
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal law and immigration law under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged ongoing validity of deportation after acquittal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code s. 430(1)(b): Mischief causing damage under $5,000
Crimes.Authority: Provincial Court, Appellate Court, Immigration Tribunal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the tripartite test for a stay of removal: serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 48(2)
Crimes.Outcome: Stay granted until humanitarian and compassionate application resolved
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of returning to St. Lucia due to domestic abuse and lack of support for children's medical needs
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children, state protection, risk from ex-partner
Crimes.Application_Error: Officer failed to consider best interests of children and available state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Available state protection in St. Lucia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience

Crimes.Violation_Type: Overstay of authorized period of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to temporary resident status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has pending H&C application, fears domestic abuse in St. Lucia
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant factors in deferral decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer focused only on practicality, ignored child welfare and risks
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada during H&C processing
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under IRPA, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Serious issue, irreparable harm to children, balance of convenience favors applicant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections on removal orders and compliance
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after removal order due to fear of domestic violence and lack of state protection
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Removed person who failed to depart
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Deferral request not adequately assessed
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children and risks in St. Lucia not considered
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remain in Canada until H&C decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant meets all three branches of the stay test

Crimes.Violation_Type: Actions placing children at risk upon removal
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA considerations regarding best interests of children
Crimes.Application_Facts: Removal would expose children to risks due to domestic violence, medical needs, and separation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irregular status due to pending proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess child protection concerns in removal decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children ignored by officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Protection for children from harm due to removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of irreparable harm to children if removed

Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – ongoing threat to life and safety
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm upon return
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – specific threats from known individual
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Considered under IRPA s. 117(9) for H&C grounds

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer breached principles of fairness by not updating the application after a two-year delay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 113(a)
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; PRRA decision stands
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged new risk was deemed implausible given prior RPD findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new or updated evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim of increased personal risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to provide updated information during the delay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with new circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — no new evidence was submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers must assess new evidence but are not required to solicit updates
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 113(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar remained in Canada after her visa expired while pursuing protection claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable — violation based on status, not false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA decision and removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, lack of updated submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide new evidence supporting continued stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Increased risk claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on PRRA application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for PRRA, correctness for jurisdictional issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural unfairness; applicant had opportunity to update but did not

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar failed to depart Canada after final removal order was issued
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged oral deferral request not documented or acknowledged
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal process

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of oral deferral request not accepted
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains valid and enforceable
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of removal order
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Set aside removal order or defer removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness, reasonableness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty to defer without clear request or practical impediment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Suspected fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was violated in assessing credibility of relationship
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision upheld; no procedural breach found

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of updated documentation or communication records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return due to changed personal circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide new evidence supporting genuine relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not disclose or substantiate marital status changes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers assess risk based on submitted evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of denied refugee claim and lack of cooperation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of sham marriage not proven but contributed to credibility concerns

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in PRRA and removal processes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA and removal officers respected natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on existing record; no duty to seek new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent claims and lack of follow-up
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must act fairly but are not required to prompt applicants for updates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Two-year delay, alleged oral deferral request
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of updated submissions or formal deferral request
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CBSA and IRCC maintained decisions were procedurally fair
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written PRRA application, removal interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a), IRPA; common law procedural fairness

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 34(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on risk as a Sikh and Akali Dal member, family ties in Canada, and best interests of a child
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident applicant under H&C consideration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA application rejected; judicial review filed
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Sikhs in India
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of disproportionate hardship; unreliable corroborative evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not sufficiently credible or substantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or undeserved hardship demonstrated; country conditions improved for Sikhs; insufficient Canadian ties to outweigh immigration compliance
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 112(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa overstay and multiple failed H&C applications, including post-removal risk assessment
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to deportation order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant (failed to depart after deportation order)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA officer's rejection of H&C application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration and removal decisions

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims regarding political affiliation and risk not adequately supported
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; deportation order upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certified question and quashing of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: PRRA officer reasonably concluded no disproportionate hardship; country conditions do not support well-founded fear; insufficient grounds to interfere
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Section 183(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, had criminal record, claimed threats in home country

Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, unless procedural fairness issue arises

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA - Risk of torture or cruel treatment (s. 115)

Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed danger due to past cooperation with U.S. law enforcement
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of credible risk; delay in applying

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the plaintiff claim damages for constructive dismissal and harassment under tort law, given her ambiguous employment status with the RCMP?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence supports intentional infliction of nervous shock but not wrongful dismissal due to ambiguous RCMP member status
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendant is liable for intentional infliction of nervous shock and negligence; no claim for wrongful dismissal upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must prove fundamental breach of employment terms for constructive dismissal
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Testimony from plaintiff, medical professionals, and colleagues deemed credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under the Crown Liability Act, the Crown is liable for torts committed by its servants within the scope of employment
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness in assessing tort claims and employment relationship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Prolonged harassment, failure of supervisors to act, toxic work environment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim for wrongful dismissal dismissed; tort claims partially successful
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical records, witness testimony, documentation of complaints
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Tort law, employment law, Crown Liability Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denial or insufficient action on harassment complaints
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Damages for constructive dismissal and harassment
Crimes.Outcome: Awarded $93,000 for mental distress; no damages for wrongful dismissal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Crown Liability Act regarding vicarious liability

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty of care under tort law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiff experienced years of harassment; supervisors failed to intervene
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of vicarious liability and standard of care
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction due to RCMP employment
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony from plaintiff, coworkers, medical experts
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None noted; evidence sufficient to establish negligence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff's testimony found credible and consistent
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Crown found vicariously liable for negligence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Compensation for harm due to employer negligence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Monetary damages
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard of reasonable foreseeability and duty of care
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Supervisors' inaction contributed to harm; conduct fell below standard of care
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Trial court with jurisdiction over federal tort claims

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the plaintiff prove severe stress and depression were caused by intentional infliction of nervous shock?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Common law tort principles, Crown Liability Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conduct was extreme and outrageous, causing visible illness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendant liable for intentional infliction of nervous shock
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show deliberate, extreme conduct causing harm
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Consistent and corroborated testimony from multiple sources
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Conduct must be extreme, outrageous, and calculated to cause mental distress
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of whether conduct meets threshold for tort
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Four years of harassment, ostracization, threats, lack of support
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld based on severity and duration of conduct
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical diagnosis of depression, asthma exacerbation, coworker accounts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Tort law, vicarious liability, workplace safety standards
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failure to investigate or discipline perpetrators
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Damages for psychological harm and lost income
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law tort of intentional infliction of mental suffering

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Male colleagues and supervisors within RCMP
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prolonged duration (four years), abuse of authority, systemic inaction
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not formally charged, but pattern of misconduct
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk to mental health and occupational stability
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Plaintiff as a woman in male-dominated force
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish pattern of harassment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff’s account supported by independent witnesses
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Civil damages rather than criminal penalty
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Tort law, human rights principles, Crown Liability Act

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Common law duties and human rights norms
Crimes.Governing_Law: Crown Liability Act, Canadian tort law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Persistent sexual comments, hostile environment, resignation due to distress
Crimes.Claimant_Status: RCMP member with statutory office status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Determining tort liability despite atypical employment status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over Crown employees
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Plaintiff testimony, medical evidence, coworker statements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None identified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff found highly credible
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Crown held vicariously liable for harassment
Crimes.Outcome: $93,000 awarded ($88,000 lost earnings, $5,000 pain and suffering) plus interest and costs
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Compensation for psychological harm and lost career opportunities
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Monetary damages
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective test for severe and outrageous conduct
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Harassment was sustained and management failed to act
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Trial court in Edmonton with federal jurisdiction

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a removal order be deferred due to child's best interests?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to comply with immigration laws but has dependent children

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Children’s lack of adequate care if parent removed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable under IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 48
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has two young Canadian-born children

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal immigration enforcement vs. provincial child welfare

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance but genuine care for children

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child under IRPA and international law

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with reporting conditions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of reporting obligations and removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Must removal officers consider children's best interests before removal?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must consider short-term best interests of children

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Pending full assessment or judicial review

Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in rejecting the applicant's refugee claim under sections 96 and 97 of the IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application, upholding the RPD's decision
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found insufficient evidence of sustained or systemic persecution; credibility not explicitly challenged but claim deemed unsubstantiated
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports, single incident of harm
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (Convention refugee), Section 97 (Person in need of protection) of IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of FGM for daughters and harm from husband's family upon return to Guinea
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence of future risk or past persecution beyond isolated incident, husband’s ability to provide protection
Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution based on Convention grounds; risk to life or cruel treatment
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court in reviewing RPD decision
Application_Factor: Country-specific risks, family protection dynamics, prior incidents
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed; no refugee status granted

Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex is required to address AstraZeneca's '762 Patent under the NOC Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of marketing post-NOC issuance, product specificity of the patent
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate improper listing
Legal_Rule: Subsection 5(1) of the NOC Regulations requires generic manufacturers to address patents listed on the register if the drug was marketed in Canada pursuant to an NOC
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper patent listing due to timing and product specificity
Key_Evidence_Considered: AstraZeneca's listing of the '762 Patent against multiple NOCs, Minister's determination on marketing timing
Legal_Framework: Regulatory framework for patent listing under NOC Regulations
Defendant_Response: Apotex argued the patent was improperly listed
Evidence_Type: Regulatory filings, patent register entries, NOC records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn Minister's decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Harkat has established a material change in circumstances warranting reconsideration of his release
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Harkat demonstrated unexplained delays, shifting evidentiary burden to the Ministers
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Judicial review involving evidence presentation and confidential information assessment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Strict conditions can mitigate potential risks
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether release poses danger to national security or any person
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balance between right to liberty and national security concerns
Crimes.Application_Factor: Demonstrated delay in removal and potential for prolonged detention
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Release under stringent monitoring and restrictions

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security if released without conditions
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Past involvement with terrorism raises security concerns
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Security certificate issued based on reasonable grounds
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Subject of a security certificate alleging engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Confidential evidence presented during judicial review
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of confidential information in assessing danger
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns over credibility mitigated by strict release conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Length of detention and lack of imminent removal
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities applied in administrative context
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 84(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention and release under security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Conditional release with stringent terms to mitigate risk

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat to national security due to association
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing concern based on security certificate
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prolonged detention due to procedural delays
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Affiliation and support for a terrorist group
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on confidential intelligence and judicial assessment
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on non-disclosed evidence in security certificate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Risk assessed as manageable under strict conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of recent activity, compliance history, and monitoring feasibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Preponderance of evidence standard in administrative detention context
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 84(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of continued detention under security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Conditional release authorized with electronic monitoring and movement restrictions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 68(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ferri, a permanent resident, was convicted of a narcotics offense, triggering automatic cancellation of his deportation stay under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Constitutional challenge to s. 68(4) raised during appeal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, IRPA provisions, Charter arguments
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacks jurisdiction to consider constitutionality of s. 68(4)
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and hearing of constitutional challenge
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deportation order under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutionality of deportation provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to lack of IAD jurisdiction over constitutional issues
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights due to denial of appeal rights after second serious offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Cancellation of deportation stay and termination of appeal
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident seeking protection from deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of heroin for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4) IRPA

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Charter challenge to s. 68(4) IRPA based on fairness and right to appeal

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Ferri argued that s. 68(4) violates Charter rights

Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of police reports or protective actions by applicant

Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Ex-partner had prior arrests but no conviction for cartel activity
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Undermined by inconsistencies and failure to report
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings on cartel involvement

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No history of harm during visitations
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Arrests but no proven kidnapping or violent acts
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low – no credible evidence of intent or capability
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Children as leverage in family conflict
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove risk of kidnapping
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations without documentary or testimonial support
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Doubted due to lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Panel found claims speculative

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Ex-partner allegedly affiliated with drug cartels
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Alleged cartel association enhancing perceived threat level
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Police had prosecuted the ex-partner previously
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of domestic violence but no proven cartel role
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate domestic violence, unproven organized crime ties
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low – state protection available and utilized
Crimes.Risk_Type: Ongoing threats from former intimate partner
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Partial – domestic violence accepted, cartel threats not
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent statements, lack of independent verification
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible (domestic violence), not credible (cartel threats)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse findings on key aspects of narrative

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant rebutted presumption of effective state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Statistical evidence insufficient without individual context
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show state protection unavailable or inadequate
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report abuse despite multiple opportunities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Presumption of state protection applies if authorities are willing and able
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic violence and fear of cartel-related harm
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to lack of engagement with state mechanisms
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Police records showing prosecution of ex-partner
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, domestic implementation via IRPA
Crimes.Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee eligibility based on indirect risk from cartel
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged membership in Los Aztecas cartel
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Asylum claimant at port of entry or inland
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Not found inadmissible, but failed to meet refugee criteria
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Alleged spillover risk from partner’s criminal activity
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Lack of evidence supporting cartel involvement

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant has a fairly arguable case to justify judicial review of the PRRA officer's decision denying humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Governing_Law: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide supporting evidence for claimed personalized risk
Evidence_Type: Lack of supporting evidence for compulsory military service risk in Albania
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence based on risk of compulsory military service in Albania
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate a fairly arguable case for judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to support the claim
Application_Factor: Personalized risk due to compulsory military service
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no serious question raised
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness not specified; assessed under fairly arguable threshold for leave

Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant not given details such as dates or locations
Application_Error: Failure to disclose specifics of allegations
Application_Factor: Right to know and respond to allegations

National_Security_Element: Alleged involvement in drug smuggling at airport
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of disclosure of specific details
Legal_Provision: Procedural fairness under Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking
Defendant_Response: Unable to meaningfully respond due to lack of details

Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Allegations based on undisclosed RCMP reports
Risk_Nexus: Security risk due to alleged criminal activity
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Applicant not informed of specific facts

Crimes.Violation_Type: Use of false documents to enter Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada with false documents and made refugee claims that were subsequently rejected
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to entry with false documents
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, use of false documents constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal pending judicial review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, country condition reports, applicants' submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Vague and speculative risk claims, lack of specific evidence on irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims found to be speculative and lacking credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of credible risk or irreparable harm; PRRA decision was thorough

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA based on alleged risks upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants demonstrated irreparable harm or serious issue to be tried for a stay of removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of forced recruitment by LTTE deemed vague and speculative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, PRRA decision record
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and risk assessment in IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced recruitment due to age and family connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk evidence despite general country conditions
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review with motion for stay of removal
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide specific, credible evidence of personal risk
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found submitted evidence insufficient rather than ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: New evidence considered but found not compelling or relevant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false statements in immigration applications

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of refugee and PRRA claims based on misrepresentation and lack of credible risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for stay of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed as speculative and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm due to age and perceived association in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of specific evidence linking applicants to targeted groups
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Motion for stay of removal during judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inadequate demonstration of irreparable harm or serious issue
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; rather, evidence presented was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Emotional harm to family not recognized as irreparable harm
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False documentation and statements in original application

Governing_Law: Section 6(5) of the Trade Marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal after initial rejection by Opposition Board
Evidence_Assessment: Similarities in appearance, sound, and usage context; common use of 'NUTRI'; overlapping product types and markets
Burden_of_Proof: Appellant failed to prove no reasonable probability of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Additional evidence presented on appeal deemed insufficient
Legal_Rule: Factors under Section 6(5) include inherent distinctiveness, length of use, nature of wares, trade channels, and resemblance
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition by Maximum Nutrition Limited due to potential confusion with NUTRI-MAX
Outcome_on_Merits: No sufficient proof of absence of confusion; registration opposed successfully
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of trademarks (NUTRI-BRAN, NUTRI-VITE vs NUTRI-MAX), product overlap, market similarity
Evidence_Type: Trademark usage evidence, product descriptions, market data
Outcome: Appeals dismissed; costs awarded to respondent
Legal_Provision: Section 6(5) of the Trade Marks Act

Legal_Issue: Failure to distinguish between humanitarian and compassionate considerations and pre-removal risk assessments
Evidence_Assessment: Risk factors relevant to humanitarian and compassionate grounds were not properly considered
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Perceived lack of risk upon return to Hungary
Legal_Rule: Section 25 IRPA for humanitarian and compassionate considerations; Sections 97, 112, 113 for pre-removal risk assessments
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on legal interpretation
Grounds_for_Claim: Conflation of H&C considerations with risk assessment, closed mind to relevant factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Family circumstances, country conditions in Hungary, individual risk factors
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer did not differentiate assessment types
Evidence_Type: Narrative submissions, country reports, personal affidavits
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and remittal for proper assessment
Outcome: Application granted, case remanded for re-evaluation under section 25 IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the consultant's actions constituted a breach of natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of natural justice
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to prove incompetence or prejudice
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit evidence, medical letters, consultant representation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to procedural fairness in immigration proceedings
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation by consultant as lawyer and omission of evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Omissions deemed professional judgment; no resulting prejudice
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to demonstrate incompetence or impact on outcome
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Clear evidence of incompetence and resulting prejudice
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Medical letters not submitted based on professional judgment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Breach of natural justice requires proven incompetence and prejudice
Crimes.Application_Factor: Consultant accompanied by another representative at interview
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of natural justice found
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false representation of being a lawyer

Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural non-compliance in submission of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Obligations under immigration application procedures
Crimes.Application_Facts: Medical letters not included in PRRA application
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not found – omissions considered professional judgment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to submit supporting documents
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Missing medical documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims not substantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing re-assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Prejudice due to procedural deficiency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Omissions not negligent; evidence unlikely to affect outcome
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether consultant incompetence led to breach of natural justice
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed credibility of affidavit claims
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove incompetence and prejudice
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Contradictions between claim and record (e.g., presence of other consultant)
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Incompetence must be clear and prejudicial to constitute breach
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to include evidence and represent properly

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'CLUB BEYMEN CLUB B' is confusingly similar to Hudson's Bay's registered trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Opposition proceedings before the Trade-Marks Opposition Board, appeal to the Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Hudson's Bay provided evidence of extensive use and advertising; BEYMEN has no Canadian market presence
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed in part; BEYMEN's application restricted to certain wares and services
Burden_of_Proof: On opponent (Hudson's Bay) to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Extensive use and recognition of Hudson's Bay's BAY/BAIE marks in Canada
Legal_Rule: Confusion is assessed based on distinctiveness, usage history, nature of goods/services, trade characteristics, and resemblance
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under trademark law
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of consumer confusion due to phonetic and visual similarity between 'BAY/BAIE' and 'BEYMEN'
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for Hudson's Bay; some goods/services removed from BEYMEN's application
Key_Evidence_Considered: Advertising and market presence of Hudson's Bay, lack of Canadian presence by BEYMEN, visual and phonetic comparison of marks
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-Marks Act, opposition and appeal procedures
Defendant_Response: BEYMEN proceeded with trademark application despite opposition
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of use, advertising, market presence
Remedy_Requested: Prevent registration of BEYMEN's mark due to likelihood of confusion
Outcome: Restriction of BEYMEN's trademark registration to non-confusing goods and services
Authority: Trade-Marks Opposition Board, Federal Court of Canada
